item.title: @elonmusk: üá®üá≥ CHINA'S MAGLEV HITS 700 KM/H IN 2 SECONDS - PLANNING 1,000 KM/H - WHILE AMERICA ARGUES ABOUT FIXI...
item.description: üá®üá≥ CHINA'S MAGLEV HITS 700 KM/H IN 2 SECONDS - PLANNING 1,000 KM/H - WHILE AMERICA ARGUES ABOUT FIXING POTHOLES China just tested a maglev platform that accelerates to 700 km/h (435 mph) in 2 seconds. Target speed: 1,000 km/h (621 mph). That's faster than commercial aircraft. On the ground. The acceleration alone is borderline violent - 0 to 435 mph in two seconds is 9.8g. Fighter jet territory. Passengers would need specialized seating just to survive the launch. But let's address reality: This is a test platform. Prototype speeds don't mean operational trains. China announces ambitious projects constantly. Some materialize (their existing 430 km/h maglev in Shanghai works). Others disappear quietly. The pattern though? They're attempting scale nobody else is. High-speed rail connecting every major city. Maglev research pushed to extremes. Infrastructure spending that makes Western investment look microscopic. Meanwhile in America: Amtrak averages 105 km/h between cities. California's high-speed rail project started in 2008, burned $10+ billion, and hasn't moved a passenger. The fastest train in the U.S. hits 240 km/h for exactly one 54-mile stretch. China's going for 1,000 km/h. Even if they only achieve 800 km/h operationally, that's still triple America's maximum. Here's why this matters beyond trains: Infrastructure capacity signals industrial capability. If China can build and operate 1,000 km/h trains, they can manufacture the precision components, power systems, and control mechanisms that transfer to aerospace, military, and manufacturing. The U.S. won the 20th century partly because it built the Interstate Highway System when others couldn't. China's betting the 21st century winner will be whoever builds impossible infrastructure first. They might fail. Engineering challenges at 1,000 km/h are extreme - air resistance, track precision, emergency braking, passenger safety. But they're trying while America argues whether to fix the L train in New York. Even Chinese failure puts them ahead. You learn more from attempting the impossible than from successfully maintaining mediocrity. Source: Xinhua, CGTN

item.title: @elonmusk: Starting in 1973, my mom ran an at home day care. Six kids, zero to 5 yrs old, 8 to 10 hrs a day, mo...
item.description: Starting in 1973, my mom ran an at home day care. Six kids, zero to 5 yrs old, 8 to 10 hrs a day, mostly by herself, for decades. Her kids still visit her. She never got a million dollar gov't grant for it. States that fund fraud in the name of compassion will get fraud alone.

item.title: @elonmusk: Similar to what's currently happening in Minnesota, an investigation into childcare facilities in Ir...
item.description: Similar to what's currently happening in Minnesota, an investigation into childcare facilities in Ireland last year revealed that 7 of the top 10 highest paid companies responsible for looking after vulnerable kids are operated by African or Muslim migrants. It also revealed massive fraud with forged documents used to secure sums of up to ‚Ç¨1 million per year per child. Below are the top 10 private companies paid the most by the Irish government to house vulnerable children : 1 - Baig & Mirza Health Services Ltd- Muhammad Usman Baig and Farhan Mirza, foreign. 2 - Comet Care Ltd - Irish 3 - Whisbay Ltd- No info. 4 - Victoria Healthcare Org Ltd- Samson Oluseyi, foreign. 5 - Reign Healthcare - Tariro Taruvinga, foreign. 6 - Good People Homecare Ltd - Gerard and Simbonile Chimbganda, foreign. (Revealed they used fake garda vetting to hire untrained migrant staff). 7 - Ideal Care Services Ltd - Jossy and Karen Akwuobi (Foreign, convicted frauster, received 6 month suspended sentence in March for hiring unvetted staff and forging garda vetting. 8 - Mary Ademola t/a Clarion Healthcare - Adeniyi Ademola, foreign. 9 - Tender Touch Services Ltd - Sylverline Chikwe, foreign. 10- Superior Health Ltd - no info.
